--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@...> wrote:
>
> On Sat, =
Oct 11, 2008 at 3:14 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> > I unders=
tand that "hierarchical, modular, and formalized" are
> > sometimes viewed =
as advantages for Grammatical Encoding (a similar
> > argument is also made=
 for L-systems, which is also grammatical).
> > While these are clearly pro=
perties you want in a programming language,
> > are these really good thing=
s for a genetic encoding? The challenge
> > with encodings is not only for =
them to theoretically express all
> > possible procedures, but also to indu=
ce a nicely coupled (smooth)
> > search space. It seems that the space indu=
ced by a strictly modular
> > and hierarchical encodings is unlikely to be =
smooth, leading to
> > brittleness. You can have things like a massive new =
module being
> > doubled in one shot (which would usually be a mess, like b=
eing born
> > with two heads) or a change at one level of the hierarchy bre=
aking the
> > rest of it entirely.
> 
> And yet if evolution stumbles upon =
a module whose usefulness stems
> from multiple occurrences, how else would=
 this be accomplished? If we
> want artificial encodings to be able to prod=
uce something like a
> mammalian brain, aren't they necessarily going to in=
corporate
> hierarchy and modularity?
> 

Derek, you probably know some of =
my thoughts on hierarchy and
modularity from discussions we've had in perso=
n, but to summarize
briefly, while I agree wholeheartedly that both are imp=
ortant
properties observed in phenotypes, the question is how did they get
=
there?  

As some people probably recall me pointing out before, nature doe=
s not
discover one leg, realize it's a good idea, and then duplicate it
som=
ewhere else.  Both legs are discovered simultaneously as an
elaboration of =
a preexisting bilaterally symmetric convention.  In
general, I believe that=
 most modules and hierarchy are the result of
such elaboration on previousl=
y established conventions, rather than
from the duplication of already-exis=
ting modules.

If an evolutionary algorithm could take a phenotypic module =
and
duplicate it easily, much of its offspring would be monstrous
amalgamat=
ions.  Nature does not generally tinker by simply duplicating
modules willy=
-nilly.   

Joe Reisinger and I wrote a position paper on this argument bac=
k in
2004 called "Exploiting Morphological Conventions for Genetic Reuse."
=
 It's still available here:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?PubID=3D1=
52

I can tell you that when I presented the ideas in this paper at the
GEC=
CO workshop in which it appeared, I recall the audience found it
controvers=
ial.  A number of people in the audience seemed to react
especially strongl=
y to my claim that "nature is not an engineer." 
Admittedly, I knew this as=
sertion would draw a reaction, but then
again, it's perfectly true.  If we =
try to bend evolution to act like a
good computer scientist, it may be akin=
 to forcing an artist to think
like an engineer.  While the concepts of eng=
ineering and computer
science such as modularity and hierarchy are naturall=
y appealing to us
as computer scientists and engineers, their traditional e=
ngineering
conception is not necessarily the right perspective for harnessi=
ng
evolution (even if they are byproducts of it).  Evolution is more a
tink=
erer than top-down (or even bottom-up) designer and its modules
most often =
result from elaborations of regularities that already exist.
